required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Vascular Function, Fish Protein Hydrolysates and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus
clinical_study.official_title: Effect of Acute Fish Protein Hydrolysates Ingestion on Vascular Function of the Type 2 Diabetes Subjects

lead_sponsor.agency: Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro

clinical_study.source: Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro

brief_summary.textblock: Type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) is a chronic metabolic disease of abnormal carbohydrate metabolism which is related with high morbidity and mortality rates caused by its complications. One of the major diabetes-related arterial phenotypes thought to be responsible for development of cardiovascular disease is endothelial dysfunction. Nitric oxide (NO) is a potent molecule derived of endothelium, which plays key role in control of vascular tone. In T2DM present endothelial dysfunction due to reduced NO bioavailability. Fish protein hydrolysates (FPH) have been showed to present antioxidant peptides (and high value of ACE inhibition activity. Therefore, the present study aimed to examine whether single dose of FPH ingestion would reversal macro- and microvascular endothelial dysfunction in T2DM.

arm_group.description: Health young subjects free of diabetes mellitus and nutritional intervention

intervention.description: 5g of the sucralose administered as white plastic capsules
5g of the FPH dissolving in 100 mL of water

facility.name: Federal University of Rio de Janeiro

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro
